sentences.sentence: Canadian bank dividends, in our view, are poised to rise - a lot.
In August, before Q3 earnings season, we argued there was no policy rationale for the continuing moratorium on dividend increases.
At the time, earnings and capital were already at all-time highs.
Moreover, the banks had set aside an enormous amount, approximately $21.4 billion, of allowances against performing loans, courtesy of the new provision accounting adopted in 2018.
This huge reserve represents a powerful firewall against unexpected losses.

There has literally never been a time in Canadian bank history where the sector was in a stronger position to pay dividends.In absolute terms, the level of dividend increases will be influenced by the strength of earnings and capital.
Last quarter, core earnings reached an all-time high of $15.1 billion, or approximately 23 per cent above pre-pandemic levels.
Over this same period, common equity Tier 1, or CET1 ratios - the world's most important capital ratio - rose 150 bps to 13 per cent.

This increase makes the Canadian banks among the best capitalized banks globally.We expect the banks will release another $4 billion to $6 billion of reserves in the next several quarters, placing continued upward pressure on both earnings and capital.
Reserve releases are typically accompanied with below-trend credit costs that would support earnings and capital.

In absence of any capital deployments or buybacks, the banks' CET1 ratios are likely headed to 13.5 per cent or higher, creating even more capacity to raise dividends.So, how much and when?In terms of how much, current earnings and capital could support immediate dividend increases of between 20 per cent and 25 per cent, even if earnings completely stalled.
At this level, the banks would return to pre-pandemic payout ratios, and capital ratios would continue to remain high.

Dividends could increase by even more if any of several catalysts emerge/strengthen: (i) sustained lower provision ratios, (ii) higher net interest margins from changes in the yield curve (in Canada or the U.S.), and/or (iii) loan growth increases as the economy reopens further.Although earnings are the biggest driver of dividends, capital is an important variable.
Should the banks seek to slow the rise in capital ratios, it is possible that dividend increases could be even larger.
Higher dividend yields would likely result in multiple expansion and this lower cost of capital could support acquisitions (all or partially financed with equity).

That said, with P/E multiples lower, at least some banks are likely to emphasize buybacks (over deployments).How one investor became a super hardcore dividend fan, and what you can learn from him(https://financialpost.com/investing/how-one-investor-became-a-super-hardcore-dividend-fan-and-what-you-can-learn-from-him)FP Answers: How can I use ETFs to build the fixed-income side of my portfolio?

(https://financialpost.com/investing/fp-answers-how-can-i-use-etfs-to-build-the-fixed-income-side-of-my-portfolio)The stock trader's guide to navigating the global energy crisis(https://financialpost.com/investing/global-investor/a-stock-traders-guide-to-navigating-the-global-energy-crisis)In terms of when, we believe dividends increases should begin this quarter.
There is simply no policy justification for the moratorium to continue and it should have been lifted two quarters ago, in our opinion.

Conventional wisdom is that dividends will rise this quarter given the federal election is over, although it was never clear to us why the election was a variable since bank dividend policy obviously does not rise to the level of important national policy.

Nevertheless, "when" and "how much" dividends will increase will depend on the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions (OSFI).The backdrop for Canadian bank stocks is likely to continue to be favourable in the coming quarters, supported by the potential for: (i) highly material dividend increases, (ii) lower provision ratios supporting both earnings and capital generation, (iii) (accretive) buybacks, and (iv) higher ROEs, as well as relatively low valuations (forward P/Es are below historic averages).Rob Wessel is managing partner of Hamilton ETFs and is a frequent commentator on the Canadian banks and global financials.

Additional insights on the sector can be found atwww.hamiltonetfs.com(https://hamiltonetfs.com/ )._____________________________________________________________If you like this story, sign up for(https://newsletters.financialpost.com/?utm_source=on-net&;utm_medium=display&;utm_campaign=fp_newsletters&;utm_content=fp_newsletters_all_homepage_banner) the FP Investor Newsletter._____________________________________________________________ !

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: Canadian bank dividends, in our view, are poised to rise - a lot. In August, before Q3 earnings season, we argued there was no policy rationale for the continuing moratorium on dividend increases. At the time, earnings and capital were already at all-time highs. Moreover, the banks had set aside an enormous amount, approximately $21.4 billion, of allowances against performing loans, courtesy of the new provision accounting adopted in 2018. This huge reserve represents a powerful firewall against unexpected losses. There has literally never been a time in Canadian bank history where the sector was in a stronger position to pay dividends.In absolute terms, the level of dividend increases will be influenced by the strength of earnings and capital. Last quarter, core earnings reached an all-time high of $15.1 billion, or approximately 23 per cent above pre-pandemic levels. Over this same period, common equity Tier 1, or CET1 ratios - the world's most important capital ratio - rose 150 bps to 13 per cent. This increase makes the Canadian banks among the best capitalized banks globally.We expect the banks will release another $4 billion to $6 billion of reserves in the next several quarters, placing continued upward pressure on both earnings and capital. Reserve releases are typically accompanied with below-trend credit costs that would support earnings and capital. In absence of any capital deployments or buybacks, the banks' CET1 ratios are likely headed to 13.5 per cent or higher, creating even more capacity to raise dividends.So, how much and when?In terms of how much, current earnings and capital could support immediate dividend increases of between 20 per cent and 25 per cent, even if earnings completely stalled. At this level, the banks would return to pre-pandemic payout ratios, and capital ratios would continue to remain high. There is simply no policy justification for the moratorium to continue and it should have been lifted two quarters ago, in our opinion. Conventional wisdom is that dividends will rise this quarter given the federal election is over, although it was never clear to us why the election was a variable since bank dividend policy obviously does not rise to the level of important national policy. Nevertheless, "when" and "how much" dividends will increase will depend on the Office of the Superintendent of Financial Institutions (OSFI).The backdrop for Canadian bank stocks is likely to continue to be favourable in the coming quarters, supported by the potential for: (i) highly material dividend increases, (ii) lower provision ratios supporting both earnings and capital generation, (iii) (accretive) buybacks, and (iv) higher ROEs, as well as relatively low valuations (forward P/Es are below historic averages).Rob Wessel is managing partner of Hamilton ETFs and is a frequent commentator on the Canadian banks and global financials.
